Edicta, with effort and dedication, wants to continue working in order to move her business forward, since in the near future, she dreams of having the possibility of setting up a store in a commercial space where she can offer a greater variety of articles and having it generate favorable profitability and economic stability to give her son an excellent education and a better quality of life.

loans.use: to buy merchandise wholesale (blouses, jeans, shoes, accessories, and perfume, among other items) to stock her store.

loans.name: Munanda Jinjenge Women Group

texts.en:
The person raising her hand in the photo is Esther, a member of Munanda Jijenge Women Group in Nakuru Kenya. She is forty-three years old, married and a mother of six. She joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa (HiH EA) in November 2013.

Esther is a maize and beans farmer. With the training she got from HiH EA, she has been able to commercialize her farming and get more profit from her business. 

Esther has asked for a Kiva loan to purchase fertilizer and quality seeds to expand her business. This will greatly boost her crop yields leading to increased incomes which will enable cater for her children school fees and other basic needs. 

She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and plant seeds.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en: Juliet is a female, 30 years of age, divorced  with three children living in Kasese, Uganda. Juliet operates a retail shop of general merchandise and has been in that business for two years. She started the business in order to look after her children as a single mother. She has a dream of expanding her business and educating her children. Inadequate capital and competition are her major challenges. Juliet will use the loan to buy salt, sugar, soap, maize flour, cassava flour and other general merchandise to sell.

loans.use: to buy salt, sugar, soap, maize flour, cassava flour and other general merchandise to sell.

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Petrona en su búsqueda por un futuro prometedor y unas buenas oportunidades para salir adelante, decidió iniciar un negocio que según ella le dará todo eso que siempre ha soñado.

Montara un negocio de cría y venta de pollos de engorde, gallinas y huevos en su casa en el municipio de Apartado, con el cual planea sacar adelante a su hijo (Ver Foto).

Para esto necesita la ayuda de un préstamo para la compra de materiales para construir un galpón y compra de gallinas ponedoras y pollos de engorde para iniciar con este negocio.

Apoya a los sueños emprendedores de una mujer Colombiana con un préstamo hoy!
texts.en:
Petrona, in her search for a promising future and some good opportunities to advance, decided to begin a business that, according to her, will give her everything that she has always dreamed of.

She will set up a business of raising and selling broiler chickens, hens, and eggs in her house in the town of Apartado. With this business, she plans to raise her son (see photo).

For this she needs the help of a loan in order to purchase materials to build a shed and to buy laying hens and chickens to raise to begin this business.

Help the entrepreneurial dreams of a Colombian woman with a loan today!

loans.use: to buy materials to build a shed and buy laying hens and broiler chickens to begin this business.

loans.name: Muhammad

texts.en:
Muhammad is 32 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has four children, with two of them currently in school. For the past seven years, Muhammad has been working hard to manage his milling machine business, which sells products like maize flour. 

To help expand his business, Muhammad has requested a loan of 4,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more maize flour for milling, and will help Muhammad to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Muhammad hopes that in the future he will be able to buy another milling machine. 

Muhammad is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Muhammad who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more maize flour for milling.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman. She has three children. She describes herself to be ambitious. She operates a retail business where she sells exam papers, books and other stationery. She has been involved in this business for 10 years. Her business is located in  a good market, and her primary customers are individuals and institutions. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the high cost of materials. 

She will use the 50,000 Kenyan shillings loan to buy more stock of exam papers, books and other items. Her business goal is to open another branch within five years. She hopes that in the future, she will be financially independent. This is her fifth loan with SMEP Microfinance Bank. The previous loan was repaid successfully.

loans.use: to buy more stock of exam papers, books and other items

loans.name: Mustula

texts.en:
Mustula is 48 years old and lives in the town of Nakaloke in the Mbale region of Uganda. He is married and has 7 children, with 3 of them currently in school. For the past 10 years, Mustula has been working hard to manage his small business, which sells charcoal. 

To help expand his business, Mustula has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale and will help Mustula to generate greater profits and pay school fees for his children. Mustula hopes that in the future he will be able to add more capital. 

Mustula is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Mustula, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Aksalat

texts.ru: Аксалат, 56 лет, замужем, 4 детей. У Аксалат среднее образование, она на протяжении многих лет занимается сельским хозяйством, начав этот бизнес с покупки одной коровы, позже Аксалат стала продавать яблони. У нее в хозяйстве есть 2 коровы, а на участке мерою 0,87 ГА она выращивает клевер и кукурузу, а также яблони. В целях дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, Аксалат обратилась в Банк «Бай-Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку бычков. Доходы от кредита она планирует откладывать на строительство нового дома для ее семьи.
texts.en: Aksalat is 56 years old, married, and has four children. She has an intermediate education, and has been working in agriculture for many years, having began in this business with the purchase of one cow, and later taking up selling apples. She now owns two cows, and grows clover, corn, and apples on .87 hectares of land. With the goal of further developing her business, Aksalat came to the Bai-Tushum bank for a 50,000 som (KGS) loan to buy bull calves. She plans to save income from use of the loan toward building a new house for her family.

loans.use: to purchase additional calves in order to earn greater profit and save money to build a house

loans.name: Moko Sane Group

texts.en:
The "Moko Sane" groups consists of 3 members whose efforts and struggles have brought them to join ID-Ghana for their 10th loan. They sell assorted cooking oil, fresh fish and smoked fish. Ivy is the representative borrower; she has been selling assorted cooking oil for 16 years. She is applying for this loan to buy more assorted cooking oil to sell to customers. This will help her to finalize her business plan and thus improve her income. She is 57 years old, married with children.

Together with their colleagues, the group members have received orientation about loans and micro finance, so they are aware of the work and efforts expected from them in a continuous and permanent manner to ultimately be successful and provide a better life for their families. They continuously monitor training and verification that somehow requires and also encourages the women to fight to escape poverty. The group needs a total amount of 4,300 GHS to improve their businesses.

loans.use: To buy more assorted cooking oil to sell to customers.

loans.name: Marziya

texts.ru: Марзия, 36 лет, замужем, вместе с супругом воспитывают 4 детей. У Марзии среднее образование, в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи, она уже много лет занимается животноводством. Благодаря упорству, целеустремленности и трудолюбию Марзии, на сегодняшний день у нее в хозяйстве есть 2 коровы. Марзия обратилась в Банк "Бай-Тушум" за кредитом в сумме 30,000 сом (KGS) на покупку быка для откорма и реализации, что поможет ей накопить средства на поступление ее дочери в университет. Марзия намерена в дальнейшем расширять свой бизнес, что непременно приведет к увеличению капитала семьи.
texts.en: Marziya is 36 years old, married, and has four children with her spouse. She has an intermediate education, and for many years has raised livestock to earn the primary source of income for her family. Thanks to her perseverance, determination and hard work Marziya today owns two cows. She contacted Bai-Tushum bank for a 30,000 som (KGS) loan to buy a calf for fattening and sale. This will help her save money to send her daughter to university. Marziya intends to expand her business in the future, which will undoubtedly bring more capital to the family.

loans.use: to purchase one bull for fattening and resale in order to earn more profit and pay for her daughter's higher education

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy sugar, soap, salt, soft drinks and other general merchandise for selling.

loans.name: Dutambutsanye Group

texts.fr:
Marc  fait partie du groupe  Dutambutsanye et  habite à  Bujumbura. Il a 42 ans et est marié à Apolline, une commerçante. Ensemble ils ont 5 enfants âgés de 1 à 17 ans, dont  3 étudient. 
Il fait le commerce de  boissons et restaurant  depuis  14 ans. 

Il est son à deuxième   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’il obtient, il va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de riz, et de l’huile de palme à revendre cuits dans son restaurant.

Dans les prochaines  années, il  voudrait  avoir un magasin d'habillement, et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Marc is a member of the Dutambutsanye group and lives in Bujumbura. He is 42 years old and married to Apolline, a saleswoman. They have five children between the ages of one and 17, three of them go to school.
He has worked in catering and the sale of beverages for 14 years.

This is his second loan from Turame. With the Kiva loan that he requests, he will increase his capital and buy a large quantity of rice and palm oil to prepare and sell in his restaurant.

In the coming years, he would like to open a clothing store and send his children to school.

loans.use: he will increase his capital and buy a large quantity of rice and palm oil to prepare and sell in his restaurant.

loans.name: Kagwa

texts.en:
Kagwa is 45 years old and lives in the town of Bulenga in the Kampala West region of Uganda. He is married and has three children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past five years, Kagwa has been working hard to manage his boutique, in which he sells clothes. 

To help expand his business, Kagwa has requested a loan of UGX 2,500,000 (Ugandan shillings) from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy more clothes to sell and will help Kagwa to generate greater profits and take care of his family's basic needs. Kagwa hopes that, in the future, he will be able to expand the business. 

Kagwa is a member of BRAC Uganda's Small Enterprise Program (SEP). The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs, like Kagwa, who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to buy more clothes to sell.

loans.name: Turavjiyemeje Group

texts.fr:
Fabiola  fait partie du groupe  Turavyiyemeje et  habite à  Bujumbura. Elle a 26 ans et est mariée à Audifax, un agent de la Régideso. Ensemble ils ont 2 enfants âgés de 1 à 4 ans.

Elle fait le commerce de bananes  depuis  5 ans. 

C’est son premier   crédit  à Turame. Avec le crédit KIVA qu’elle obtient, elle  va  augmenter son capital et acheter  une grande quantité de bananes  à revendre pour gagner plus. 

Dans les prochaines  années, elle voudrait  construire une maison, et voir ses enfants étudier.
texts.en:
Fabiola is a member of the Turavyiyemeje group and lives in Bujumbura. She is 26 years old and married to Audifax, a Regideso agent. They have two children aged one and four years old.

She has been selling bananas for five years.

This is her first loan from Turame. With the Kiva loan that she requests, she will increase her capital and buy a large quantity of bananas for resale to earn more.

In the coming years, she would like to build a house and send her children to school.

loans.use: she will increase her capital and buy a large quantity of bananas for resale to earn more.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and open a workshop from home.

loans.name: Patience

texts.en:
Patience is 32 years old and lives in the town of Masaka in the Masaka region of Uganda. She is married and has three children who are all currently in school. For the past four years, Patience has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells essential items like sugar, soap, beans, and rice. 

To help expand her business, Patience has requested a loan of 3,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more essential items for sale, and will help Patience to generate greater profits and increase her income for the family. Patience hopes that in the future she will be able to expand her business further. 

Patience is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Patience who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more essential items for sale

loans.name: Gulzhan

texts.ru: Гулжан 37 лет, замужем, 3 детей. У Гулжан среднее образование, с 2000 года в качестве основного дохода для своей семьи занимается сельским хозяйством. У нее в хозяйстве есть 3 коровы, 2 теленка. Гулжан продает экологически чистое, вкусное, домашнее молоко, которое пользуется большим спросом. Она известна, как принципиальный, честный, порядочный и надежный человек. Ежемесячный доход Гулжан составляет 20,000 сом (KGS). Для дальнейшего развития своего хозяйства, она обратилась в Банк «Бай – Тушум» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку телят, для увеличения поголовья скота. Доходы от кредита Гулжан планирует использовать для развития своего хозяйства.
texts.en:
Gulzhan is 37 and married with three children. She has a high school education and has been working in agriculture since 2000 as the primary source of income for her family. She has three cows and two calves and sells delicious organic milk, which is in high demand. She is known as a principled, honest, decent and hopeful person and has a monthly income of 20,000 KGS.

In order to further develop her business, Gulzhan has turned to Bai Tushum Bank for a loan of 100,000 KGS to purchase calves to increase her head count of livestock. She plans to put profits from the loan into further developing her business.

loans.use: to buy additional calves to invest in further growth of her business

loans.name: Kenkonzi  Mubuku Women Group

texts.en:
Susan is 45 years old, married, and has six children. She lives in Kasese, Uganda. Susan sells fresh foods, such as onions, tomatoes, and other vegetables, which she has been doing since 1993. 

Susan requested a loan, which she will use to buy onions and tomatoes to sell. She dreams of expanding her business into other towns despite the challenge of perishability of her products.

loans.use: to purchase onions and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Njoki

texts.en:
Njoki is a married woman with two kids who attend school and are under her care. She lives at a rental house that  has electricity but no  piped water. 

For over two and half years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling from door to door and from home to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. 

With the loan of Kes 25,000 that she is requesting, she wants to purchase a bale of used clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase a bale of used clothes for resale

loans.name: Mwaye Credit Group

texts.en: Joyce is a 54-year-old widow with 4 children who go to school. She started her small grocery store ten years ago, selling various goods such as soap, salt, sugar, and biscuits. She is requesting this loan to buy assorted items in bulk, in order to satisfy her customers' needs. Her plan is to use any profits generated to start constructing a big building for her grocery business, and to pay school fees for her children.With the previous profits she has been able to feed her family three meals a day.

loans.use: To purchase assorted groceries

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr: AKOUA est mariée et mère de deux enfants ;âgée de 55ans, elle est commerçante de diverses boissons et s’approvisionne une fois par mois au grand marché de Lomé, puis loge à Adidogomé dans une maison dont le toit est en tuile, se nourrit deux fois par jour mais ne dispose pas de moyen de déplacement. AKOUA désire un crédit pour soutenir son commerce, mieux épargner et partager les charges avec son mari et surtout répondre aux besoins de sa clientèle qui ne cesse de s’augmenter avec d’autres demandes de nouvelles variétés de produits.
texts.en: Akoua is married with two children. She is 55 years old and sells various beverages. She buys supplies once a month at the big market in Lome. She lives in Adidogomé in a house with a tiled roof and eats twice a day, but does not have any means of transport. Akoua requests a loan to support her business, to save more and to be able to share expenses with her husband. Above all, she hopes to be able to satisfy the needs of her customers. Her clientele is growing daily and asking for other services and new varieties of products.

loans.use: to buy 03 cartons of rum,10 cartons of whisky and 08 cartons of gin.

loans.name: Shakti Annapurna Shg Group

texts.en:
Shakti Annapurna Self Help Group consists of nine women from a village of Talbarkot, Dhenkanal in Odisha. They formed a group to help themselves, to share their problems and to solve their problems among them.
 
One of them is Sabita, who was selected as the President of Shakti Annapurna Self Help Group.The lady standing with raised hand in the photo is Sabita. Sabita is 38 years old and lives with her husband and her 16-year-old son. Her son is pursuing intermediate science. Sabita  is able to utilize her extra time  weaving bedsheets and winter wear and that skill helps her to earn money.

She has requested a group loan of 180,000 INR, from which her portion will help her to purchase the require resources for weaving. She says a portion of the loan amount will help her to purchase a sewing machine, velvet cotton, stones, wool, needles, thread, and cover operational expenses like labor charges.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine,velvet cotton, stones, wool, needles, thread, and to cover operational expenses like labor charges

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase new clothes to sell to her customers.
